frequent_values: What is the difference between Public Housing and Section 8?
Do I have to have a source of income to be eligible to apply for public housing?
Can I list a specific development as my preference on my application?
Do I need to have children living in my household to be eligible to apply for public housing?

shortest_values: How much will my rent be?
Are utilities included in my rent?
How often should I file an application?
How do I apply for public housing with NYCHA?
longest_values: Changes to your family size, source of income or amount of income may affect the placement of your application, if you are not certain whether to report the change, you may contact the Customer Contact Center for information or re-file a new application with the updated information. "

An emancipated minor is a child who has been granted the status of adulthood by a court order or other formal arrangement. In the United States, there are three main ways for a teenager to become emancipated and they are: Court petition; Marriage and Military Service. "
Get a Paper Application Call or visit NYCHA’s Customer Contact Center to get a paper application Submit a request to have an application mailed to you. "
The Section 8 Program enables eligible persons to rent privately owned apartments. Housing assistance payments are made to the private landlords.
Do I need to have children living in my household to be eligible to apply for public housing?

frequent_values: The goal of the Working Family Preference is to maintain the stability, diversity and healthy income mix for the population of public housing.
No, you do not have to be a resident of New York City to apply, but due to NYCHA’s long waiting list, available apartments will be offered to applicants who live or work in New York City first.
You must be at least 18 years or older, or an emancipated minor to be eligible to apply for public housing.

Your rent will be based on 30% of your household’s anticipated gross annual income less deductions. HUD regulations allow deductions of $480 for each dependent; $400 for elderly family, or a person with a disability; and some medical deductions for households headed by an elderly person or person with disabilities.

No, you do not need to submit documents with the NYCHA public housing application. The information you provide on your application will be verified if and when we are able to reach your application for an eligibility interview. Please do not send any documents with your application. (If you are applying for NYCHA public housing as a Victim of Domestic Violence, please see these guidelines regarding supporting documents.)

shortest_values: No, single adults are eligible to apply for public housing.
No, you are not required to have income to be eligible to apply.
You must be at least 18 years or older, or an emancipated minor to be eligible to apply for public housing.
You must immediately notify the Customer Contact Center of any change to your mailing address or telephone number(s).
You or your co-head of household must be at least 62 years or older and all other household members must be 62 years of age or older.
longest_values: The information you provided on your most recent public housing application will determine when we may be able to invite you for an Eligibility Interview. It is therefore important that you notify us of any changes as soon as it occurs. Your application is selected by computer for an eligibility interview based on your borough choice, apartment size, housing priority and date of application. However, due to the large number of families on the waiting list, and the low turnover and vacancy rate of apartments, it is impossible to estimate when a family might be selected for an eligibility interview.

No, you do not need to submit documents with the NYCHA public housing application. The information you provide on your application will be verified if and when we are able to reach your application for an eligibility interview. Please do not send any documents with your application. (If you are applying for NYCHA public housing as a Victim of Domestic Violence, please see these guidelines regarding supporting documents.)

Applicants will receive a letter from NYCHA within 45 days acknowledging the date your application was received and the housing priority that you have been assigned based on the information provided in your application. If you do not receive such a letter from NYCHA, please contact the Customer Contact Center at (718)-707-7771 from 8 AM – 5PM, Monday through Friday.

No, you may not apply for a specific development. You may only list a 1st and 2nd choice of borough (Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, Staten Island) on your application. If you are found eligible for public housing after your eligibility interview, you will be placed on a borough or development waiting list depending upon your priority and bedroom size required.

Your rent will be based on 30% of your household’s anticipated gross annual income less deductions. HUD regulations allow deductions of $480 for each dependent; $400 for elderly family, or a person with a disability; and some medical deductions for households headed by an elderly person or person with disabilities.
